Instructions to test this update (click to expand)

Either download from Cachix:

nix-store -r /nix/store/1nry6k5yn522ycgxsavvnm5817rq1v8i-zstd-1.5.5-kernel-bin \
  --option binary-caches 'https://cache.nixos.org/ https://nix-community.cachix.org/' \
  --option trusted-public-keys '
  nix-community.cachix.org-1:mB9FSh9qf2dCimDSUo8Zy7bkq5CX+/rkCWyvRCYg3Fs=
  cache.nixos.org-1:6NCHdD59X431o0gWypbMrAURkbJ16ZPMQFGspcDShjY=
  '

(The Cachix cache is only trusted for this store-path realization.)
For the Cachix download to work, your user must be in the trusted-users list or you can use sudo since root is effectively trusted.

Or, build yourself:

nix-build -A zstd https://github.com/r-ryantm/nixpkgs/archive/a5a51eebbfb24f238724fe3964f64f99f7fc4af1.tar.gz

Or:

nix build github:r-ryantm/nixpkgs/a5a51eebbfb24f238724fe3964f64f99f7fc4af1#zstd

After you've downloaded or built it, look at the files and if there are any, run the binaries:

ls -la /nix/store/1nry6k5yn522ycgxsavvnm5817rq1v8i-zstd-1.5.5-kernel-bin
ls -la /nix/store/1nry6k5yn522ycgxsavvnm5817rq1v8i-zstd-1.5.5-kernel-bin/bin

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Closes #303878

Notes:
I needed to add $out/bin to PATH because the strips assume every other script is available from PATH.
I stored the runtime dependencies inside buildInputs, but was debating changing it to a custom name, like runtimeDeps

items.title: git-toolbelt: init at 1.9.1

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Closes: #305440

This PR adds support to dub-to-nix for processing other types of entries in dub.selections.json.
It will now be able to parse and prefetch git-type dependencies and it will filter out path type dependencies.

I also added the relevant logic to buildDubPackage that copies the directory fetched by fetchgit to the appropriate location.

I temporarily added the sideloader package's derivation to the PR to show that it works.
Edit: I've removed it.

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)
    • x86_64-linux
    • aarch64-linux

items.title: git-town: 14.0.0 -> 14.1.0

items.content_html:
Motivation for this change

This is required for doing anything with git-cvsimport. I thought
about adding a cvsSupport option like for Subversion, but it only adds
0.1MB to the closure size, and is only added when perl support is
enabled anyway, so it's not worth it.

Things done
  • Tested using sandboxing (nix.useSandbox on NixOS, or option sandbox in nix.conf on non-NixOS linux)
  • Built on platform(s)
    • NixOS
    • macOS
    • other Linux distributions
  • Tested via one or more NixOS test(s) if existing and applicable for the change (look inside nixos/tests)
  • Tested compilation of all pkgs that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review wip"
  • Tested execution of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • Determined the impact on package closure size (by running nix path-info -S before and after)
  • Ensured that relevant documentation is up to date
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

items.title: git-co-author: init at 0.2.0

items.content_html:
Bot-based backport to staging-23.11, triggered by a label in #255203.

  • Before merging, ensure that this backport is acceptable for the release.
    • Even as a non-commiter, if you find that it is not acceptable, leave a comment.
items.title: [Backport staging-23.11] nodejs: make buildNpmPackage git dep lockfile fixup fail gracefully when no lockfile exists and git deps forced

items.content_html:
Motivation for this change

When running nix run nixpkgs.git-lfs -c git-lfs install, the update git config and the generated hook do not refer to git-lfs in its full path resulting in GUI applications and CLI commands outside of nix-shell to fail.

Patch git-lfs to install the git-lfs hook and configuration using the absolute path to the git-lfs command. Doing so makes the git-lfs installation pure as it won't depend on an impure PATH.

Things done
  • Tested using sandboxing (nix.useSandbox on NixOS, or option sandbox in nix.conf on non-NixOS linux)
  • Built on platform(s)
    • NixOS
    • macOS
    • other Linux distributions
  • Tested via one or more NixOS test(s) if existing and applicable for the change (look inside nixos/tests)
  • Tested compilation of all pkgs that depend on this change using nix-shell -p nixpkgs-review --run "nixpkgs-review wip"
  • Tested execution of all binary files (usually in ./result/bin/)
  • Determined the impact on package closure size (by running nix path-info -S before and after)
  • Ensured that relevant documentation is up to date
  • Fits CONTRIBUTING.md.

closes #85264

items.title: git-interactive-rebase-tool: fix build with rust 1.77

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This PR replaces the recursive fetch of the package source by non-recursive fetches of the corresponding (sub-)modules. This allows to fully take advantage of the more efficient specialized fetchers, is more robust in presence of network issues, and allows for reusing sub-modules if they don't change between updates. Furthermore, it can be a starting point for reducing code duplication caused by the sub-modules (e.g. 4 times googletest, 3 times abseil or 2 times protobuf - not even counting the possibility of just using available nixpkgs packages instead of some of the submodules).

Things done

  • Built on platform(s)

items.title: grpc: unroll recursive git retrieval

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Splitting up #257780, part 1 (I'm probably going to rewrite some of it, now that I know a bit more about nixpkgs)

This switches from building with a source tarball to cloning the repository directly. From what I understand, this is common practice, but it's a lot slower.

This is a much smaller change so hopefully it doesn't get stalled like my last attempt.

items.title: llvmPackages_git: update to 19.0.0-unstable-2024-04-14

items.content_html:
Description of changes

Fix these issues(#183344 and #30742).
This patch does the same thing of cargo-vendor --no-merge-sources.
It puts git sources to 'git-<sha>' directory.

items.title: fishPlugin.fish-git-abbr: init at 19-06-23

items.content_html:
Description of changes

This PR replaces the recursive fetch of the package source by non-recursive fetches of the corresponding (sub-)modules. This allows using the more efficient specialized fetchers, is more robust in presence of network issues, and allows for reusing sub-modules if they don't change between updates. Furthermore, it can be a starting point for reducing code duplication caused by the sub-modules.

Fixes #276585

items.title: python311Packages.torch: unroll recursive git retrieval

items.content_html:
Description of changes

We used to build calibre using its official tarball. However, the tarball contains lots of generated code such as javascript generated from python, python generated from pyqt... It also contained generated man pages.

The main difficulty to build calibre from git source is that it downloads six packages from internet, some of them is irreproducible. This commit patches that code in the following principles:

  1. The fewer changed the better.
  2. If a downloaded package is not pinned to a rev, pin it to a latest rev.
  3. If a downloaded package can't be pinned to a rev (such as downloading from https://code.calibre-ebook.com/ua-popularity), store it in nixpkgs.
  4. Allow passing downloaded packages using environment variable so user can override them when needed

items.title: calibre: build it from git source instead of tarball

items.content_html:
Description of changes

On Darwin, git-radar assumes that prefixed coreutils gstat, greadlink etc. are available in PATH, see e.g.:

  • https://github.com/michaeldfallen/git-radar/blob/2ac25e3d1047cdf19f15bc894ff39449b83d65d4/git-radar#L7-L11
  • https://github.com/michaeldfallen/git-radar/blob/2ac25e3d1047cdf19f15bc894ff39449b83d65d4/radar-base.sh#L144-L151

When they are not available, git-radar will fail with an error message:

$ ./result/bin/git-radar --bash
./result/bin/git-radar: line 13: greadlink: command not found

This PR adds a Darwin-only wrapper to add the prefixed coreutils to the script's PATH.
